title: CodeIt: Abstract Reasoning with Iterative Policy-Guided Program Synthesis [original]
meta_review:
The paper presents CodeIt, an iterative program synthesis approach to solve the Abstraction and Reasoning Corpus (ARC) benchmark. The method iterates between sampling programs from a language model policy and learning the policy using supervised learning. The sampling stage uses hindsight relabeling and program mutation to augment the programs. The method is evaluated on the ARC benchmark, where it achieves state-of-the-art performance.

The paper received four reviews, all of which rated the paper as marginally below the acceptance threshold. The reviewers raised several concerns, including the limited novelty of the method, the lack of evaluation on other benchmarks, and the absence of discussion on limitations. The authors provided a response to the reviews, but unfortunately, the reviewers did not update their scores.

### justification_for_why_not_higher_score

The paper received four reviews, all of which rated the paper as marginally below the acceptance threshold. The reviewers raised several concerns, including the limited novelty of the method, the lack of evaluation on other benchmarks, and the absence of discussion on limitations. The authors provided a response to the reviews, but unfortunately, the reviewers did not update their scores.

title: CodeIt: Abstract Reasoning with Iterative Policy-Guided Program Synthesis [no_conclusion]
meta_review:
This paper proposes a program synthesis approach to solve the ARC benchmark. The approach iterates between sampling from the current large language model policy and learning that policy using supervised learning. The sampling stage augments newfound programs using hindsight relabeling and program mutation, requiring no expert search procedure. The authors demonstrate the effectiveness of their approach on the ARC benchmark, achieving state-of-the-art performance.

Strengths: The paper is well-written and easy to follow. The proposed method is well-motivated and easy to understand. The empirical results are promising, with the proposed method achieving state-of-the-art performance on the ARC benchmark. The proposed method is simple yet effective. The proposed method is easy to implement and does not require any expert search procedure, making it a practical approach for solving the ARC benchmark. The paper provides a comprehensive review of the related work and compares the proposed method with several state-of-the-art approaches on the ARC benchmark.

Weaknesses: The proposed method is not scalable. The method requires a large number of programs to be sampled and stored in the buffer, which makes it difficult to apply to large-scale problems. The method relies on a pre-trained language model, which is not always available. The method is not generalizable. The method is designed specifically for the ARC benchmark and may not work for other problems.

### justification_for_why_not_higher_score

The method relies on a pre-trained language model, which is not always available. The method is not generalizable. The method is designed specifically for the ARC benchmark and may not work for other problems.

title: CodeIt: Abstract Reasoning with Iterative Policy-Guided Program Synthesis [no_abstract]
meta_review:
This paper proposes a novel approach to solving the Abstraction and Reasoning Corpus (ARC) benchmark, which is a challenging problem in artificial intelligence. The authors propose an iterative learning method that combines a language model with a domain-specific language (DSL) to generate programs that solve ARC tasks. The method is evaluated on the ARC benchmark and is shown to outperform previous methods.

The reviewers raised several concerns about the paper, including the lack of clear motivation for the proposed method, the lack of comparison with other methods, and the lack of discussion of the limitations of the proposed method. The authors did not provide any responses to these concerns.

title: CodeIt: Abstract Reasoning with Iterative Policy-Guided Program Synthesis [no_introduction]
meta_review:
This paper presents an approach to program synthesis that uses a language model to generate programs for the ARC benchmark. The language model is first pretrained on a dataset of programs, and then fine-tuned through an iterative process of generating programs and learning from the generated programs. The proposed approach achieves state-of-the-art performance on the ARC benchmark.

The reviewers raised several concerns about the paper, including the lack of novelty, the lack of clarity in the description of the approach, and the lack of analysis of the results. The authors provided some responses to these concerns, but they were not sufficient to address the reviewers' concerns.

title: CodeIt: Abstract Reasoning with Iterative Policy-Guided Program Synthesis [no_experiments]
meta_review:
This paper proposes CodeIt, a program synthesis approach that leverages a higher level of abstraction through a domain-specific language. CodeIt iterates between sampling from the current large language model policy and learning that policy using supervised learning. The sampling stage augments newfound programs using hindsight relabeling and program mutation, requiring no expert search procedure. The paper demonstrates CodeItâ€™s effectiveness on the ARC benchmark, showing that learning to write code in iterations leads to intertask generalization, resulting in state-of-the-art performance.

The paper received 4 reviews, all of which are negative. The reviewers raised several concerns, including the limited novelty of the method, the lack of convincing experiments, and the requirement of a domain-specific language (DSL) to be defined for each domain. The authors did not provide a response to the reviews.

title: CodeIt: Abstract Reasoning with Iterative Policy-Guided Program Synthesis [no_methods]
meta_review:
This paper proposes a program synthesis approach that leverages a higher level of abstraction through a domain-specific language. The method iterates between sampling from the current large language model policy and learning that policy using supervised learning. The sampling stage augments newfound programs using hindsight relabeling and program mutation, requiring no expert search procedure. The paper demonstrates the effectiveness of the proposed approach on the ARC benchmark, showing that learning to write code in iterations leads to intertask generalization, resulting in state-of-the-art performance.

The reviewers agree that the paper is well-written and easy to follow. The proposed method is novel and effective. The empirical results demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed approach. The reviewers also agree that the paper does not provide a detailed analysis of the computational cost of the proposed approach, the generalization ability of the proposed approach, and the robustness of the proposed approach. The authors are encouraged to address these limitations in the final version of the paper.
